title-group.article-title: Importance of monitoring blood viscosity during cardiopulmonary bypass

author-notes.corresp: Ralph E. Holsworth, Jr. Tacoma Clinic Renton, WA, USA Email: drholsworth_80907@yahoo.com

body.p: Approximately 500,000 cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) procedures using extracorporeal circulation are performed annually in the United States of America.. For decades, attention has focused on cerebral complications as a source of morbidity and disability post procedures. These deficits include impaired consciousness, seizures, cognitive impairment (memory, attention deficits, language difficulty) and stroke, all potentially limiting the ability to function independently. The reported incidence of neurological complications varies widely from 7 to 61% for transient deficits and 1.6 to 23% for permanent deficits.1 Furthermore, a late decline in cognitive performance (42% at 5 years) may be related to the previous surgical procedure.2

Cardiopulmonary bypass involves interventions; hemodilution and lowering core body temperature, which have opposing effects on blood viscosity. Hemodilution on CPB decreases blood viscosity, can increase cerebral blood flow and can alter oxygen metabolism.3,4 However, an excessive increase in cerebral blood flow may possibly lead to an additional embolic load to the brain, elevating the risk in microembolic injury. Karkouti et al. proposed a moderate level of hemodilution during CPB, with an optimal nadir hematocrit, ranging between 21-25%.5 Oxygen transport is optimized by supplemental oxygen and monitored using pulse oximetry. Core body temperature is purposely decreased during CPB. This lower temperature decreases metabolic demand for oxygen as well as increasing blood viscosity.

Microcirculatory blood flow is governed by perfusion pressure, a vessel’s radius and length, and blood viscosity. Blood viscosity can increase by 50 to 300% when the temperature of blood is decreased from 37°C to 22°C.6 One can argue that this increased blood viscosity would have no practical effect on tissue perfusion because pump output can be controlled and optimized by the perfusionist. However, hypoxia and capillary ischemia with normal or even increased local blood flow have been documented in diabetes and in venous insufficiency. This is due to microvascular shunts, which have been demonstrated in the brain.7 One can envision these shunts allowing blood to bypass capillaries congested with hyperviscous blood, creating local ischemia. Measuring systemic pH to determine the adequacy of tissue perfusion may not be sensitive in detecting such local hypoperfusion caused by pathologic microvascular autoregulation.

Previous work has shown the importance of blood viscosity in the macrovasculature. The Edinburgh Artery Study reported on the relationship of blood viscosity and elevated carotid intima-media thickening (IMT) in 1106 adults.8 Adult men demonstrated that blood viscosity (p≤0.001) and hematocrit (p≤0.05) were linearly related to carotid IMT. Multivariate analysis revealed that blood viscosity (p≤0.01) remained significantly associated with carotid IMT. Separately, stroke patients have been shown to have chronically elevated blood viscosity levels.9 Lowe et al. reported on the link between blood viscosity and cardiovascular events in 1592 adults.10 After adjusting for age and gender, viscosity, hematocrit, and hematocrit-corrected viscosity were significantly higher (p=0.0003) in patients with cardiovascular disease than those without disease. Measured rheological variables were equal or stronger than conventional risk factors such as diastolic blood pressure and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-c) for the occurrence of cardiovascular events. After adjusting for conventional risk factors, the association with blood viscosity and hematocrit remained significant only for stroke.

The blood viscosity profile, i.e., the viscosity over a broad range of shear rates, including those seen in both the micro- and macrovasculature, potentially could provide valuable information for improving perfusion management of CPB patients, given the neurological complications following cardiac surgery. Rheological studies directed at the management of these surgical patients have not yet been performed. However, blood viscosity data in this population could provide a better basis for intra-operative and post-operative management of patients in an effort to minimize neurological complications.
